questions.text: Heartburn is an uncomfortable burning feeling in your chest. This can be a symptom of many conditions, including acid reflux, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and pregnancy. All of the following are true about Heartburn (pyrosis) EXCEPT:

options.label: B
options.text: A discomfort or burning sensation behind the sternum

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased with drinking water Heartburn is a substernal warmth or discomfort that moves up toward the neck; meals often exacerbate that and may awaken the patient. Associated symptoms include regurgitation of acid or nonacidic fluid and water brash, the reflex release of salty saliva into the mouth. Most cases of heartburn result from excess acid reflux, but reflux of weakly acidic or nonacidic fluid can produce similar symptoms. Ten percent of patients with heartburn exhibit no acidic or nonacidic esophageal reflux and are considered to have functional heartburn. The discomfort is relieved with drinking water or antacid but can occur frequently, interfering with everyday activities, including sleep.

questions.text: What is the defect in the Achalasia of the esophagus?

options.label: A
options.text: Loss of excitatory ganglion cells of Meissner's plexus

options.label: B
options.text: Loss of both excitatory and inhibitory ganglion cells of Meissner's plexus

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of excitatory ganglion cells of myenteric plexus

options.label: D
options.text: Loss of both excitatory and inhibitory ganglion cells of myenteric plexus

questions.correct_answer: D. Loss of both excitatory and inhibitory ganglion cells of myenteric plexus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Loss of both excitatory and inhibitory ganglion cells of myenteric plexus Achalasia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. With long-standing illness, aganglionosis is noted. The condition involves excitatory (cholinergic) and inhibitory (nitric oxide) ganglionic neurons. The basic pathophysiology is abnormal esophageal peristalsis and incomplete lower oesophageal relaxation. Absent peristalsis and failure of deglutition LES relaxation are the defining features of achalasia. Achalasia with esophageal dilatation, tapering at the gastroesophagea junction, and an air-fluid level within the esophagus. The example on the left shows sigmoid deformity with very advanced disease.

Extraedge:

Allgrove syndrome or 3A(aaa)syndrome ACTH-resistant adrenal insufficiency Alacrimia Achalasia cardia

questions.text: Identify the associated pathology with the imaging:

Spastic achalasia High-resolution manometry has advanced the diagnosis; three subtypes of achalasia are differentiated based on the pattern of pressurization in the nonperistaltic esophagus. The manometric findings are in Type3/spastic achalasia. The upper esophageal sphincter will relax with swallowing, and the lower esophageal sphincter will fail to relax ; IRP will be >15 mm of mercury, and there is premature contraction. The distal latency will be less than 4.5 sec.

Types of Achalasia Cardia Type 1 - (complete damage to both Acetylcholine and NO-producing fibers) No peristalsis . Failure of relaxation of LES.The terminal event of type 2 and type 3 Type 2 - Incomplete destruction of Myentric plexus Peristalsis is preserved to compartmentalization or pan-esophageal pressurization. Failure of LES relaxation Type 3 - Selective damage to the nitric oxide producing fibers–unopposed action of acetylcholine—--premature contraction with failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax

In high-resolution manometry, black means the High-pressure zone, and blue is the low-pressure zone. Black to blue, the pressure decreases. The components in this manometry that are used to diagnose esophageal motility disorders are Distal contractile integral DCI, Integrated Relaxation pressure-IRP, Distal Latency, Resting LES Pressure, and UES pressure.

Episodes of dysphagia and chest pain attributable to abnormal esophageal contractions with regular deglutition LES relaxation manifest DES . questions.text: Which of the following is endorsed by current societal guidelines for managing high-grade dysplasia in the esophagus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Endoscopic mucosal ablation The finding of dysplasia in Barrett’s exceptionally high-grade dysplasia mandates further intervention. In addition to the high rate of progression to adenocarcinoma, there is also a high prevalence of unrecognized coexisting cancer with high-grade dysplasia. Treatment recommendations for Barrett’s esophagus with high-grade dysplasia have evolved over the past several years. Historically, esophagectomy was the gold standard treatment for high-grade dysplasia. However, esophagectomy has mortality ranging from 3 to 10%, along with substantial morbidity. Recent prospective studies have demonstrated the efficacy of mucosal ablation therapy with substantially less morbidity and essentially no mortality . Consequently, current societal guidelines endorse endoscopic mucosal ablation therapies for managing high-grade dysplasia.

questions.text: A 32-year male has a history of daily awakenings in the middle of the night due to epigastric pain for about a month now, which gets relieved with antacids. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duodenal ulcer Epigastric pain, described as a burning or gnawing discomfort, can be present in DU and GU. The typical pain pattern in DU occurs 90 min to 3 h after a meal and is frequently relieved by antacids or food. Pain that awakens the patient from sleep (between midnight and 3 a.m.) is the most discriminating symptom, with two-thirds of DU patients describing this same complaint. This symptom also exists in one-third of patients with NUD (Nonulcer Dyspepsia).

questions.text: After swallowing a steak, a 47-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for chest pain that developed at a restaurant. He reports intermittent episodes of meat getting stuck in his lower chest over the past three years but none as severe as this event. He denies food regurgitation outside of these episodes or heartburn symptoms. He can swallow liquids without difficulty and has not had any weight loss. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Schatzki's ring A lower esophageal mucosal or B ring is a thin membranous narrowing at the squamocolumnar mucosal junction. Its origin is unknown, but B rings are demonstrable in ~10–15% of the general population and are usually asymptomatic. When the lumen diameter is < 13 mm, distal rings are usually associated with episodic solid food dysphagia and are called Schatzki rings. Patients typically present older than 40 years, consistent with an acquired rather than congenital origin. Schatzki ring is one of the most common causes of intermittent food impaction, or “ steakhouse syndrome, ” because the meat is a typical instigator. Symptomatic rings are readily treated by dilation.

questions.text: A 36-year-old female with AIDS and a CD4 count of 35/ cubic mm presents with odynophagia and progressive dysphagia. The patient reports a daily fever and 9 kg weight loss. She has been treated with clotrimazole without relief. GPE shoes BMI 16, temp-100.8ºF. examination of the oropharynx reveals no evidence of oral thrush. The patient undergoes upper GI endoscopy, revealing serpiginous ulcers in the distal esophagus without vesicles. No yellow plaques were noted. A biopsy was taken, which showed intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions in the larger endothelial cells and fibroblast. What is the best treatment for this patient's esophagitis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ganciclovir Among AIDS patients, infectious esophagitis becomes more common as the CD4 count declines. Cases are rare with a CD4 count >200 and common when a CD4 count is < 100 . HIV may also be associated with a self-limited syndrome of acute esophageal ulceration with oral ulcers. Regardless of the infectious agent, odynophagia is a characteristic symptom of infectious esophagitis. CMV esophagitis occurs primarily in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV, patients with malignancy, and recipients of bone marrow or organ transplants. CMV is usually activated from a latent stage. On endoscopy, CMV lesions appear as large serpiginous ulcers in normal mucosa, particularly in the distal esophagus. Biopsies from the ulcer bases have the most significant diagnostic yield for finding the pathognomonic large nuclear or cytoplasmic inclusion bodies. Immunohistology with monoclonal antibodies to CMV and in situ hybridization tests are helpful for early diagnosis. Treatment studies of CMV gastrointestinal disease have demonstrated the effectiveness of both ganciclovir (5 mg/kg every 12 h IV) and valganciclovir (900 mg orally every 12 h) . Therapy is continued until healing, which may take 3–6 weeks. Maintenance therapy may be needed for patients with relapsing disease. The patient has symptoms of esophagitis, and various infections can cause this disease, including herpes simplex virus, CMV, varicella zoster virus, candida, and HIV itself.

questions.text: A patient presents with dysphagia to both solids and liquids, and esophageal manometry was performed; it revealed failed peristalsis, compartmentalization, and isobaric pressure of the esophagus is 100 mmHg. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Type 2 achalasia The given history is suggestive of achalasia cardia. The diagnostic criteria for achalasia with esophageal manometry are impaired LES relaxation and absent peristalsis. High-resolution manometry has advanced this diagnosis. Three subtypes of achalasia are differentiated based on the pattern of pressurization in the non-peristaltic esophagus. Because manometry identifies early disease before esophageal dilatation and food retention, it is the most sensitive diagnostic test.

Type 1 – Failed peristalsis, no pressurization, no esophagogastric flow. Type 2- Failed peristalsis, compartmentalized pressurization >= 20% pan-esophageal pressure, esophagogastric flow- isobaric pressure> LES pressure. Type 3 - Spastic, propagating contracture.

questions.text: The patient presents with halitosis and swelling in the lateral aspect of the neck, which gives rise to a regurgitant air sound on pressing. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pharyngeal pouch Esophageal diverticula are categorized by location, with the most common being. Epiphrenic, Hypopharyngeal (Zenker’s), and Mid-oesophageal. Epiphrenic and Zenker’s diverticula are false diverticula involving herniation of the mucosa and submucosa through the muscular layer of the esophagus. These lesions result from increased intraluminal pressure associated with distal obstruction. In the case of Zenker’s, the obstruction is a stenotic cricopharyngeus muscle (upper esophageal sphincter), and the hypopharyngeal herniation most commonly occurs in an area of natural weakness proximal to the cricopharyngeus known as Killian’s triangle. Small Zenker’s diverticula are usually asymptomatic, but when they enlarge sufficiently to retain food and saliva, they can be associated with dysphagia, halitosis, and aspiration .

It is also commonly called “steakhouse syndrome” from meat getting stuck in the ring.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes with the complaints of easy fatigability and intermittent dysphagia to solid food. She has also had a history of heavy menstrual bleeding for the last few months. She has pallor on examination. Upper GI endoscopy showed webs in the proximal esophagus. What is the likely diagnosis?

Solution:

Plummer Vinson syndrome The combination of symptomatic proximal esophageal webs and iron-deficiency anemia in middle-aged women constitutes Plummer-Vinson or Paterson-Kelly syndrome. Depending on the degree of impingement, they can cause intermittent dysphagia to solids similar to Schatzki rings and are similarly treated with dilation.

questions.text: A patient with a history of recurrent cold and dry, thickened skin with intense pruritus complains of on-and-off dysphagia and a sensation of impaction of food while eating. Upper GI endoscopy was done and showed the below picture; what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Eosinophilic esophagitis As per symptoms, the patient above has a prior history of allergic rhinitis and atopic dermatitis. Eosinophilic esophagitis is an immunologic disorder induced by antigen sensitization in susceptible individuals . Food allergens are the dominant triggers. EoE should be strongly considered in children and adults with dysphagia and esophageal food impactions . Other symptoms in adults may include atypical chest pain and heartburn. An atopic history of IgE-mediated food allergy, asthma, eczema, and/or allergic rhinitis is present in the majority of patients. The characteristic endoscopically identified esophageal findings include loss of vascular markings (edema), multiple esophageal rings, longitudinally oriented furrows, and whitish exudate. Histologic confirmation is made with the demonstration of esophageal mucosal eosinophilia (peak density ≥15 eosinophils per high-power field) The goals of EoE management are symptom control and the prevention of complications. Primary therapy often starts with PPI therapy, effectively improving eosinophilic inflammation in 30–50% of patients. Additional first-line therapies include elimination diets or swallowed topical glucocorticoids. Elemental formula diets devoid of allergenic protein are highly effective therapy but are limited by palatability.
